conclusion: Determine the number of molecules of the gas using given conditions and ideal gas law.
At state A: T_A = -73°C = 200 K, P_A = 3 x 10^5 Pa, V_A = 1 x 10^-3 m^3. At state C: T_C = 273 K, P_C = 1 x 10^5 Pa, V_C = 4 x 10^-3 m^3.
The ideal gas law is PV = nRT.
Calculate the number of moles at state A: n_A = (3 x 10^5 x 1 x 10^-3) / (8.31 x 200) ≈ 0.018 mol.
Calculate the number of moles at state C: n_C = (1 x 10^5 x 4 x 10^-3) / (8.31 x 273) ≈ 0.018 mol.
Since the number of moles remains constant, n_A = n_C.
Convert moles to molecules: Number of molecules = 0.018 x 6.0 x 10^23 ≈ 1.1 x 10^22.
Verify internal energy change: ΔU = nC_vΔT with ΔT = 73 K and ΔU = 200 J.
The number of molecules of the gas is approximately 1.1 x 10^22.
